ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
HIGH COURT JUDGES
(Additional Appointments)


    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland asked the Chief Secretary if - in view of the long delays in the setting down of cases in the High Court for hearing or trial, and in view also of the representations which have been made by the Bar Committee, the Singapore Chamber of Commerce and the Malayan Exchange Banks Association that additional High Court Judges should be appointed - he will make a statement on Government's proposals in the matter of making such additional appointments.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Sir, as I stated yesterday, provision has been made in the Estimates for next year for an additional appointment of Puisne Judge, thus raising the number of Puisne Judges to five.

    Mr Sutherland: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder if the Chief Secretary could tell us whether, in view of the fact that in no one month this year have there been less than 270 cases awaiting trial for which no date or hearing could be given in the fixing of the list, he could give us some idea why there has been such a long delay in making a fresh appointment?

APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [2nd Allotted Day]:

    Resumption of debate on amendment (21st November, 1956) proposed to Head 26 in the First Schedule of the Bill,

    "To reduce by $100,000 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 3, Family Planning Association, on page 144 of the Estimates."-(Mr Goh Tong Liang).

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]


FIRST SCHEDULE


    Head 26-

    The Chairman: We are on Head 26 and I would inform hon. Members that there are 60 minutes left for that head. The Question is -

    Mr D. S. Marshall (Cairnhill): Mr Chairman, Sir, could I enquire whether, in view of the other amendments available and the desire of some Members, including myself, to speak on the Main Question and draw attention to other items under this heading, you could, Mr Chairman, allocate part of the available time for this heading for the purposes of this amendment?

    The Chairman: I am afraid I am bound by Standing Orders. The hon. Member is aware that time has had to be allotted for each head of expenditure, and I do not think I can deviate from Standing Orders.

    Question again proposed,

    "That the sum to be allotted for Head 26 be reduced by $100,000 in respect of subhead 3, Family Planning Association, appearing on page 144 of the Estimates."

10.06 a.m.

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Mr Chairman, I think at the outset I ought to say that I appreciate your timely halting of yesterday's debate at the moment of interruption, when emotions and feelings were running high owing to taunts being hurled at me as I was addressing the Committee on what

Column: 907

is to me a serious subject. If in a moment of heat I said anything unseemly, I wish to apologise to hon. Members and particularly to my ministerial colleagues.

    At the adjournment yesterday, Mr Chairman, I was explaining to hon. Members that I had been trying as much as possible to reduce expenditure on medical buildings without lowering standards, and I said that construction of the new Training School, the Nurses Hostel and several clinics and outdoor dispensaries, which the former Government had estimated to be built at $80,000 each, had cost $50,000 each, a saving of $30,000 each. I have nothing more to add to what I said yesterday, Mr Chairman, except this: that with the sum of $100,000, the Government can build two more such clinics or outdoor dispensaries in such parts of the island as may need them, and they would give much better service to the country than does the Family Planning Association which, in my opinion, should be a voluntary organisation and should not be subsidised by Government.

    In conclusion, I would like to draw hon. Members' attention to Head 26, page 145, and see some of the other charitable grants which have been provided for in the Budget:

    After-Care Association - only $10,000.

    Little Sisters of the Poor (a most deserving cause) - only $4,800.

    School for the Deaf (another very deserving cause) - only $6,000.

    Singapore Youth Council - only $15,000.

    I would like to see all these grants increased rather than to see $100,000 voted for the Family Planning Association.

    When I returned home last night, I received this so-called interesting pamphlet which was sent to me by the members of the Family Planning Association and which was alluded to by the member for Tanglin yesterday.

Column: 908

In the Encyclical of Pope Pius XI on Christian Marriage His Holiness declared:

    "Any use whatsoever of matrimony exercised in such a way that the act is deliberately frustrated in its natural power to generate life is an offence against the law of God and of nature, and those who indulge in such are branded with the guilt of a grave sin."

If hon. Members are interested and wish to read the Encyclical of His Holiness I shall supply them with a copy.

    There is also this comment:

    "As regard the evil use of matrimony - to pass over the arguments which are shameful ones - not infrequently - others that are false and exaggerated are put forward. Holy Mother Church very well understands and clearly appreciates all that is said regarding the health of the mother and the danger to her life; and who would not grieve to think of these things?".

In the discourse to midwives it was accepted that in very serious cases of ill-health or where the mother's life is in danger, the use of the "safety period" is permissible.

    Mr Chairman and hon. Members, I have nothing further to add to what I have said except to urge you, with all the force at my command, not to agree that this colossal sum of $100,000 be given to this Association when that money can be utilised for very much more useful purposes.

10.11 a.m.

    The Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas): Mr Chairman, Sir, in view of the number of Members who wish to speak on other items under this Head, I think it is important that we should exercise not birth control but speech control, and I shall therefore make mine as short as I can.

    There are only two points to which I wish to refer. The first is a practical point of national implication in this amendment. The Minister for Health has conceded that the information given by the Family Planning Association can properly be given in Government clinics where it is required, and it seems clear to me that if we deprive the Association of financial support, it will either have to reduce its work very considerably or will have to wind itself up.

Column: 909

There will then be an increased burden thrown on to the public revenue by people having to go to the Government clinics for advice there, and we shall merely be transferring the load from the Charitable Allowances and Grants Head to the Ministry of Health Head. I have no doubt that in the transfer the amount of money involved will very considerably increase, because you will have removed the voluntary unpaid element which at present is very considerable. The final effect will be a much heavier burden on the funds of the country. Incidentally, that, of course, disposes also of the argument that Catholics should not be forced to contribute to family planning work, because the government funds are derived from Catholics as well as from others, and if the Ministry of Health is going to provide these services, then the Catholics must still be contributing in so far as they are good citizens and pay their income tax and other taxes.

    There is one other argument put up which I feel deserves a moment of time. It was suggested that if the Family Planning Association continued its work, we should suffer from a lack of manpower for our Singapore Battalion and pan-Malayan development work. This is a very long-term view indeed. During the immediate future, all you would get would be an increase in baby-power, and I do not think baby-power is very significant either in soldiering or in working. If you take the period from the time of conception to the time the living soul becomes effective from a working or a soldiering point of view, say, 18 years, and stop family planning, it could not possibly have any significant effect until about 1975, which is indeed a long-term view. By 1975 some 400,000 boys and girls now already alive, and many of them in school, will have been added to the effective labour force. I do not think we need fear any absence of manpower in those circumstances. It is a most ill-conceived argument based, I am afraid, on a complete failure to distinguish between an infant in arms and a worker at his lathe.

Column: 910



    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Sir, I think we should all look on this subject of family planning from an objective viewpoint and we should not be influenced by our beliefs or outside forces. The only consideration that we should put before us is whether this expenditure of $100,000 will benefit Singapore or whether it will do us no good at all. To my mind, we have the examples of China, India and Japan whose governments have adopted family planning and they do so not because they want it but because of necessity, because of over-population and the impossibility to food and clothe all the children being born in those territories. These countries will not adopt family planning unless it is vitally necessary and we in Singapore are coming to that stage. We have now over 20,000 people unemployed and their numbers are increasing, and this has been confirmed by the Minister for Commerce and Industry. On top of that, we have those people who are now leaving school and trying to find employment and their numbers will be increased. I can assure the Members of this House that the question of unemployment is very serious. There can be no more rubber packing in Singapore because it is not economical to pack here due to the rise in wages, and you have over a thousand people unemployed on that account alone. In my opinion, if an expenditure of $100,000 can save a thousand or even a few hundred people from the embarrassment and worry of having to meet confinement expenses and the support of a new mouth in the family, I think the money is well spent. If we can save a few hundred women from the worry of an unplanned confinement and going through the sufferings of ill-health and having to visit quack doctors in order to obtain abortion, which may injure their health and possibly cause their death, then we shall have spent this money well.

    Sir, I would ask Members of this House to view this expenditure of $100,000 objectively, and if we are not influenced by our beliefs and outside forces, our common sense will tell us that it is money worth spending.

Column: 911



    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Mr Chairman, Sir, I also will exercise speech control. I would just like to touch on one angle of this debate. Last year several people outside the Assembly accused us of treating this subject with the utmost levity. Some of the remarks passed in this Committee may have bordered on the salacious, but much of what was said was said with conviction and sincerity. In any case, what is so terrible about having a dig or a jest at the expense of family planning? The birth of a human being may be the greatest of all mysteries, but there is no mystery about contraception, or should not be! One member said he was surprised that there should be joking about such a serious subject. That seems to me to be bordering on the sanctimonious. We have had laughter in this House, Sir, on many occasions and sometimes it has relieved tension. At times it has taken place in discussions far more serious than this one. My own view is that I refuse to regard the subject of family plan, fling as holy ground. I believe that the Family Planning Association consists of a group of people who are absolutely sincere in their convictions and are of impeccable reputation. I think the work they are doing, which is largely voluntary, is in the very best tradition of voluntary workers in that they are devoting their time to the relief of sufferers and to the poor. As such, I think they are deserving of government assistance. That I believe, Sir, and I have heard no argument so far which will ever shake that belief.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Chairman, Sir, someone has said that speech, like pregnancy, is easy to conceive but hard to deliver. That is why there have been some unplanned speeches and certain ill-advised deliveries! Sir, last year the subject was thoroughly debated and this year I find that most of the speakers who took part in the debate last year find it unnecessary to repeat the performance. But I do see, Sir, that the Minister for Health still maintains that planned parenthood is unhealthy. I am very happy, too, to see that the Minister for Communications and Works, while not maintaining that

Column: 912

there should be more communications and less work, still makes out a case for planned parenthood.

    Sir, I have asked for the figures since 1950 of the amounts of contribution or grants to this Association. It began in 1950 with $5,000 and it kept on mounting up - 1951, $10,000; 1952, $20,000; 1953, $30,000; 1954, $45,000; 1955, $60,000; 1956, $85,000; and next year, $100,000. Every year when this vote was being debated in the Assembly, there had been opposition. It would appear, Sir, that opposition to the Family Planning Association makes it more thriving and makes it more worthy of support. We are proposing to increase the grant by $15,000 in 1957, and in 1958, with the record of service that they have rendered to the people of Singapore, I should not be surprised if the $100,000 is exceeded. Sir, the F.P.A. is rendering a service which my Ministry, the Ministry of Labour and Welfare, while looking after labour still has to look after its welfare, maintains that it is a sum worth spending.

    Mr Marshall: If it please you, Sir, yesterday I said that this was an unfortunate and unnecessary amendment. I hope the voting on it will prove it unnecessary, and I think it has been amply proved that the debate has been unfortunate. The subject seems to exacerbate feelings deeply held and produces an emotional incapacity for logical thought and an excitement as indicated in yesterday's wild attack on me personally by the Minister for Health.

    Sir, as for the lack of logic in the approach, I would draw your attention to the Minister for Health's statement made proudly that he is building several maternity clinics and hospitals, and in those maternity clinics and hospitals for which we obtain money from the public by tax in order to support them, family planning advice is given. Sir, if this Government can use money obtained by tax for the support of clinics and hospitals which, as part of their work, give advice on family planning, where is this evil which he sees in -

    Mr Braga rose -

    The Chairman: Point of order?

Column: 913



    Mr Braga: Point of clarification, Sir.

    The Chairman: Will the hon. Member give way?

    Mr Marshall: No, Sir. Where is this evil which is alleged to exist in the utilisation of money directed to an organisation whose integrity and whose approach to this human problem has not been challenged either in this House or outside?

    Sir, there was one other matter brought up by the Member for Changi to which I would like to reply. He said that these dedicated ladies in the Family Planning Association have very rich husbands, so let them go and sell their jewellery -

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Sure, sure!

    Mr Marshall: I would say this, Sir. I know the Member for Changi is a sincere social worker. I have seen him go into court. I have seen him bail prisoners. I have seen him do quiet work for the public. But I say this to him. Would he give his all for any one particular aspect of the social services in which he is interested? Is it not good that there are people who do come forward to give not merely money but of their time to serve the people? Let us remember that the $100,000 is but a part of the budget of the Family Planning Association and that the persons to whom the Member for Changi has referred do, in fact, give their voluntary donations to the extent that they can, but they do appeal to the public and the public does support this Family Planning Association. So I say, with respect to the Member for Changi whom I have always regarded very highly, that that jibe was uncalled for.

    I can only hope, Sir, that the absence of many of the supporters of family planning who voted last year will in no way affect a matter which gravely affects an important social service for this territory, and that some who abstained last year will take courage to support a very worthy cause.

    Mr Braga: Mr Chairman, Sir, I wish to correct a statement that was made by the Member for Cairnhill just now.

Column: 914

Subject to correction, Sir, I do not think that I ever said that free advice on family planning is given in the maternity clinics and hospitals; what I did say was that if any woman, for reasons of health, requires advice on matters of that nature -

    Mr Marshall: Family planning?

    Mr Braga: Not necessarily family planning, but advice on matters of health. She can get that advice in the maternity clinics and hospitals, but as far as I know, these centres do not give such advice on family planning as advocated by the Family Planning Association. [Interruption.]

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng crossed the Floor of the House.

    The Chairman: Order. The hon. Member is completely out of order in crossing the floor unnecessarily. Will he please return that document?

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Yes, Sir. I apologise for crossing the Floor, Mr Chairman. Please forgive me for taking that particular document. The reason is that I wish to refer to it and answer back.

    In my speech yesterday I did not advise those office bearers in the Family Planning Association to sell their jewellery. I advised them to save that money and not to spend it on diamond rings and beautiful dresses.

    I must thank the Member for Cairnhill for his nice compliment on my social service activities. Sir, as a social worker, I have had occasion to attend many social functions. Sir, I wonder whether or not the Little Sisters of the Poor can be classified as an institution which has rendered a great service to this country?

    Hon. Members: Sure.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Yes, but when I looked through the Budget, I failed to find the Little Sisters of the Poor applying for any government grant.

    Mr Marshall: On a point of information, Sir. The Member for Changi will

Column: 915

find there is a grant for the Little Sisters of the Poor at page 145, Head 26, subhead 24 of the Budget.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: I beg your pardon, Sir. Because the debate has been so heated and so sensational, I failed to observe this. I thought it was the Blue Cross Charitable Institution. Sir, the Blue Cross is a recognised institution and is run by public donations. If the House will allow me, I will organise more social functions and render greater service to this country without a government donation.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): On a point of order, Sir. Has the Member for Changi indicated the length of time he requires to speak on this subject, Sir, and has he used up all that time?

    The Chairman: That is not a point of order. I have allotted 100 minutes for the whole of Head 26. I take it that hon. Members are aware of it and that they are also aware that there are two more amendments put down for debate. There are just over 30 minutes left.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Thank you, Mr Chairman, Sir. Besides the two points which I pointed out yesterday, I wish to add another point - public spirit. We are most appreciative of the work done by these energetic and devoted ladies for the Family Planning Association. I am wondering whether they cannot take another step forward and also direct their attention to the Blue Cross Charitable Institution which is run on a voluntary basis. I believe the money spent on the Blue Cross Charitable Institution is much less than that spent on the Family Planning Association. The relief done by the Blue Cross is an indication of its public spirit. So I wish the office bearers of the Family Planning Association would try to understand my point of view and give it careful consideration if they wish to run the Association on a voluntary basis. If the advice that they give is not only to be confined to family planning but also to other matters, then I am in support of this grant.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

    To reduce by $5,000 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 18, Grant to Automobile Association of Singapore, on page 144 of the Estimates.

    Sir, I am glad that under the "Remarks" column this grant requires Treasury sanction and I do hope that such sanction will not be approved. This Association is a private body and is affiliated to all the other motoring associations in the British Commonwealth. I do not see why we should provide a grant to a private association. $5,000 is required, Sir, and from the reasons given, I see that this sum is to

Column: 917

assist the Association to replace existing road signs with new ones. Road signs are, in fact, the responsibility of the Government or the highway authority, which is the City Council. It should not be the responsibility of a private association to provide road signs. I am told that such road signs are put up for the purpose of guiding motorists to different places of interest. It is more or less in the nature of tourist propaganda and it should therefore be the responsibility of the Government and not of private association.

    The Automobile Association of Singapore is maintained by the members. I am myself a life member of the Association and, as such, I should have been very happy to see that a grant is provided for it. But it is a principle that is involved, Sir. It is not the question of a grant that is coming to my Association. I am very much against the principle of granting money out of public funds to a private association. As the Minister for Health has indicated in his speech on family planning, it is the policy of the money that is involved. I hope that Treasury sanction will not be given and I trust that the House will support my amendment.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Francis Thomas: The explanation is very simple, Mr Chairman, Sir. If the hon. Member will look at page 418 of the Estimates, he will see a rather fuller explanation of what it is proposed that the Association should do. A distinction is drawn between the signs which give orders, say, "Stop" or "Keep left" - which are definite orders - and those which give useful information such as the fact that there is a narrow bridge ahead or you are coming to a double bend and that kind of thing.

    The grant in this case is a dollar-for-dollar grant and, in fact, if the Association is not given the grant and it does not put the signs up, then the burden will be transferred to the Government. The advocates of less taxation, I am sure, will support this grant which will cost only $5,000 from the public

Column: 918

funds, whereas if the Association is not allowed to co-operate with the Government, then presumably the whole amount will have to be paid from the public funds, or will not be provided, with less improvement consequently in the traffic situation. There is undoubtedly very great need for improvements of all sorts in the safety and rapid flow of traffic in Singapore, and anything that can be done should be done. If the Government organisation has to be extended to deal with these things that will, of course, involve not only expenditure on signs but expenditure on additional officials to go round and see where the signs are to be put up. There is very often a real saving to be achieved by using a voluntary organisation to do work which the Government could do but which would be costly and elaborate and which would perhaps be slower because everything has to go through the government machine.

    I should add perhaps that the Traffic Branch of the Police, who, after all, are experts on this problem, strongly support this vote, and that the signs to be erected will be erected in consultation with the Traffic Branch both as to types and location. I hope my explanation is sufficient, Sir, for us to pass on to other items. It is, in fact, a saving of money and probably an increase in efficiency will be derived from making this grant to a voluntary organisation which can do useful work in the public service.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, it is really surprising to hear from the Minister for Communications and Works that if the road signs were to become the responsibility of the Government, the expenditure involved would be more. There was the opinion frequently expressed yesterday that broadcasting should come under private enterprise. Is it the Minister's contention that whatever is undertaken by the Government will cost far more than if it is undertaken by private enterprise? If that is so, I am very much surprised.

    On the question of road signs, Sir, I am fully aware, as I have indicated in

Column: 919

my speech, that it is not a question of "Stop, look, go", but it is a question of "Major road ahead" or "Sharp bend" as indicated by the Minister. All the way up to the Federation, Sir, I do find such signs and it is my opinion that they should be provided by the Government rather than by a private organisation, if the Automobile Association of Singapore is trying to help motorists, it should apply for a grant from the Commonwealth Headquarters Association to which it is affiliated, rather than from the Assembly. I do not think it is right for the Government to grant a dollar for a dollar, a dollar for a dollar, to all kinds of organisation. I shall be coming back to this dollar for dollar basis on another issue at a later stage. I think this is entirely wrong. As the Member for Changi has indicated earlier, because the Blue Cross is doing charitable work in place of the Government, and if that organisation is going to apply for a dollar for dollar grant, then the Government will be committed to a colossal sum of money. As it stands today, Sir, we are committed to $1,078,520 just for charity alone, and if more associations come to Government for dollar for dollar grants, where will it land? We are faced with a deficit of $36 million, Sir, and out of that the Member for Cairnhill has indicated that $14 million or $15 million is provided for four minesweepers. Out of that charity, another $16 million to $20 million may have to be provided in time to come. Can this Government afford that, Sir?

    Mr Marshall: if it please you, Sir, I must confess that I fail to understand the Member for Queenstown. Surely he does not discourage voluntary organisations of citizens seeking to serve their fellow citizens? This is a voluntary organisation. It is recognised that it is doing very useful work. It is recognised that it has inadequate funds to do this work competently and fully unless it receives assistance. Therefore, rather than take over the work which would deprive citizens of, for one thing, the opportunity to serve the country and which

Column: 920

would also increase the cost to Government, Government has very wisely said, "We will give you half of what it costs for a service that is essential to the country." If the hon. Member is complaining about a million dollars to charity, all I can say, for my part, is "Not enough."

    I would like to see, Sir, for example, since the Minister for Communications and Works has shown the interest of his department in the welfare of the road user, that there should be a greater grant to the Safety First Council to enable it to reorganise itself on an efficient basis. It is no use giving a little. You cannot get much in return; but if you give adequately, then you can assist the voluntary organisations to better efforts and to far greater returns than the outlay which is indicated.

    Government should not, as a matter of principle, take over all charitable organisations. Voluntary charitable organisations are a very valuable asset to the people of the country and to those who have an opportunity to serve. For myself, Sir, I would like to say this: I will never be chary in supporting Government in all legitimate measures, even generous measures, to assist charitable organisations to discharge the functions they seek to discharge to the maximum possible efficiency.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Sir, the Member for Queenstown claims to be a business man, and I am unable to understand why he cannot see the mathematics of this case. Surely the saving is not only a dollar for a dollar, but the time that Government officers would take to design and put up all these sign posts?
